quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
nums[3] = nums[1]
print(nums[3])
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Operations[/h1]

The item at a certain index in a list can be reassigned.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="315"]nums = [7, 7, 7, 7, 7]
nums[2] = 5
print(nums)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[7, 7, 5, 7, 7]
>>>[/code]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to create a list, reassign its 2nd element and print the whole list.
[!raw!]
nums = [33, 42, 56{0}
nums[{1}] = 22
print({2})
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Operations [/h1]

Lists can be added and multiplied in the same way as strings.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="316"]nums = [1, 2, 3]
print(nums + [4, 5, 6])
print(nums * 3)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3]
>>>[/code]
[note]Lists and strings are similar in many ways - strings can be thought of as lists of characters that can't be changed.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
nums = [10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5]
nums[0] = nums[1] - 5
if 4 in nums:
  print(nums[3])
else:
  print(nums[4])
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Operations[/h1]

To check if an item is in a list, the [b]in[/b] operator can be used. It returns [b]True[/b] if the item occurs one or more times in the list, and [b]False[/b] if it doesn't. [code format="py" codeId="317"]words = ["spam", "egg", "spam", "sausage"]
print("spam" [b]in [/b]words)
print("egg" [b]in [/b]words)
print("tomato" [b]in [/b]words)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
True
True
False
>>>[/code]
[note]The [b]in[/b] operator is also used to determine whether or not a string is a substring of another string.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to print "Yes" if the list contains 'z':
[!raw!]
letters = ['a', 'b', 'z']
{0} "z" {1} letters:
  print("Yes")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Operations[/h1]

To check if an item is not in a list, you can use the [b]not [/b]operator in one of the following ways:[code format="py" codeId="318"]nums = [1, 2, 3]
print([b]not [/b]4 in nums)
print(4 [b]not [/b]in nums)
print([b]not [/b]3 in nums)
print(3 [b]not [/b]in nums)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
True
True
False
False
>>>[/code]
